Dear MEREDITH SMILLIE:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
January 26, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12214 Compliance with the child protection law
An agency shall comply with the child protections
l aw, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Three of three new employee files reviewed did not have documentation the agency
was in compliance with the child protection law.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
r eport.
Two of three special investigations reviewed did not have a report completed within
15 days of the conclusion of the investigation.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/20/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/13/2023
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s
health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the
child.
2

(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster
family, including information about siblings who do
not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency
m edical care.
Two of six foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-j of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlined within the rule.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/20/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/13/2023
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the
home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
a nd at least once every 90 calendar days.
Four of six foster care files reviewed (8 of 25 service plans) did not have the
Updated Service Plan/Initial Service Plan completed timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

(2) An agency social service worker shall visit the

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting

FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, step-
down from a residential or hospital setting, return from
AWOLP, or request for change in foster home/relative
placements.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Monthly supervision social work contacts need to be coded correctly in
MISACWIS.
• Annotations on PATP’s need to be dated.
• Verification of CPR/First should be uploaded in CWLM.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. SIR
2023C0000406 was initiated on 4/18/2023 regarding allegations the agency did
not provide known mental health or behavioral information regarding a youth to
foster parents when seeking placement. The investigation determined violation of
rule 400.12417 (1) foster parent information. A CAP was approved on 5/26/2023
and was completed.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
renewal inspection completed on 12/20/2022 with a corrective action plan
approved on 1/13/2023. During the review the agency had nineteen violations.
Ten violations were noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. Four of
the citations found during this year’s audit were repeats from the 2022 renewal.
Six of the citations found during this year’s inspection were repeats from the past
two inspections. During this period under review the agency noted that overall
compliance was impacted, in part, by staff turnover.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency experienced some difficulty in meeting
requirements during this review period. The agency has experienced staff
turnover. In addition to staff turnover, the agency has experienced some
challenges related to locating available homes for high needs youth. This has
added to the job stress and somewhat impacted the ability to comply with licensing
rules. The Chief Administrator noted there is one caseworker that has struggled
6

with timeliness. The agency has been proactive to work with Human Resources to
develop performance coaching plans to assist staff.
The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the previous year CAP yielded some
improvements. The agency focused on training and enhanced supervisory
oversight. The CA noted the agency utilizes MMR and KPI reports to track
compliance. In addition, the CA noted the agency regularly reviews the previous
year CAP during monthly leadership meetings, supervision and individual team
meetings. The CA expressed confidence that several areas will improve over the
next review period.
Financial Overview
Financial records were reviewed and there were no concerns identified.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors are available and coworkers assist as
needed. Staff did not report any concerns or areas of need.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and adoption services. All files were stored
securely including CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Agency Analyst identified one safety concern as follows:
Safety Alert #1: The licensed foster home made an appointment with Agency
Analyst to conduct a home visit, however they were not home at the time of the
appointment. In addition, they did not respond to several phone calls or messages to
reschedule.
Resolution: Agency Chief Administrator advised Agency Analyst the licensed foster
home closed their foster home license the previous month.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
